item.title: [SPR-3257] Cannot find "lang" namespace handler unless all library jars are present
item.description:
Up until 2.0.3 it worked fine for the groovy bean definitions with the following xml:

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>
<beans xmlns="http://www.springframework.org/schema/beans" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance"
xmlns:lang="http://www.springframework.org/schema/lang"
xsi:schemaLocation="
http://www.springframework.org/schema/beans http://www.springframework.org/schema/beans/spring-beans-2.0.xsd
http://www.springframework.org/schema/lang http://www.springframework.org/schema/lang/spring-lang-2.0.xsd"
default-init-method="init">

<lang:groovy id="someGroovyBean" script-source="classpath:com/mycompany/SomeGroovyBean.groovy">
<lang:property name="dataSource" ref="dataSource"/>
</lang:groovy>

but it fails in 2.0.3 with the following exception:

org.springframework.beans.factory.parsing.BeanDefinitionParsingException: Configuration problem: Unable to locate NamespaceHandler for namespace http://www.springframework.org/schema/lang
Offending resource: class path resource [testContext.xml]

at org.springframework.beans.factory.parsing.FailFastProblemReporter.error(FailFastProblemReporter.java:68)
at org.springframework.beans.factory.parsing.ReaderContext.error(ReaderContext.java:85)
.... etc.
item.summary: Cannot find "lang" namespace handler unless all library jars are present

status.description: A resolution has been taken, and it is awaiting verification by reporter. From here issues are either reopened, or are closed.

comments.comment:
As far as I know, there are 2 possible reasons for that problem. Reason 1. There is something wrong with the META-INF/spring.handlers. Reason 2. You have not included the beashell and jruby required libraries in your classpath. In spring 2.0.3, the LangNamespaceHandler.java file requires that both groovy, beanshell and jruby libraries must be exists in the classpath in order to register the LangNamespaceHandler. Without beanshell and JRuby libraries, the LangNamespaceHandler.java will throw ClassNotFound exception which can be viewed if you enable the log level to ALL.

You can try to add the bsh-2.0b4.jar and jruby.jar to your classpath and see if the above exception is gone. If the exception still exist, you can try to investigate whether there is something wrong with the META-INF/spring.handler file. The groovy, beanshell and jruby dependency problem is already reported in the following link:
http://opensource.atlassian.com/projects/spring/browse/SPR-3250

There may be other possible reasons that cause the exception which I don't know.

cheers
chris tam
xenium

Well, then I would vote for relaxing the dependency requirements. Why would I need jruby and bsh deps if I only want to use Groovy beans?

As indicated in my SPR-3250 comment, this was an accident: We need to be able to parse and validate XML files which happen to use the lang namespace even without the libraries being present on the classpath (in particular for Spring IDE). Something went wrong in addressing that, suddenly throwing NoClassDefFoundError in normal runtime mode. This will be fixed in 2.0.4.

Juergen
Roger that Thanks a lot Juergen!

Strange: This stuff does work for me! Groovy scripts run fine without JRuby on the classpath. I tried Sun's JDK 1.6.0 as well as 1.5.0_10...

The root point is that the NamespaceHandler can be properly loaded on my machine, with failures only occuring once specific ScriptFactory instances are about to created. For some reason, the stacktrace above indicates a linkage error at the time of loading the LangNamespaceHandler class already, despite that class not directly referring to specific JRuby classes (or any other specific classes)...

Any details on setup and scenarios would be appreciated. Please try to set up a minimal test case with a plain Groovy script defined through <lang:groovy> and see whether you still get JRuby failures.

Juergen
